content:
Hey Lisa, please fix the first test, it has some random spaces in this line:

.........k.......G x n D..

that messes up with some solutions (like `dd`.split in ruby).

This looks fun. Nice clash! :)
"LisaWishesSheHadFewerIdeasLisaWishesSheHadFewerIdeasLisaWishesSheHadFewerIdeasLisaWishesSheHadFewerIdeasLisaWishesSheHadFewerIdeas" - love this, haha.

âœ… Approved the contribution.
Comment: Unlike other problems I have seen so far. Thank you.

âœ… Approved the contribution.
Comment: Pretty doable, even in reverse mode!

Interesting concept in place! Liked the square grid and decipher using characters for appropriate rows and columns.

I am just daunted about seeing it later in reverse mode, maybe harder to keep a count of 26x26 grid and understanding the use of the text after it, that too in mixed cases. Should actual numbers there paired or separated by numbers instead help it become decipherable without such a clear goal statement?

Also, why are all grids sparse? I wonder is it missing a few testcases where the grid is mostly to completely filled, without much '.' voids?

Rest looks well to me.

âœ… Approved the contribution.
Comment: lgtm. Doable and fun in reverse

Interesting messages. Your creation brings a smile to my face again :)

Constraints section
* Please mention the lower limits of the lengths of [[secretCode]] and [[message]].

* Please mention that the length of [[secretCode]] is always even.

* The extra semi-colon may be removed.

Thanks.

Ahh, thanks :)

I made the suggested changes and added two more tests/validators to test the min and max

Hey -- Thanks and thanks for the feedback.  

These aren't bad suggestions at all, but I hesitate to put too much into a Clash.  Therefore I had to "make decisions" about what this specific Clash is.

The joy of this to me is that letters show the coordinates of letters!!  That to me twisted my brain in a good way.  (Another clash, might use numbers for the coordinates, and that would be fine too.)

I am keeping the grid size consistent throughout (always 26 x 26) to make that a "non-issue" (to keep the Clash simple), but it does give that sparseness.  Again, your suggestion is not bad, just not for this particular Clash.

I agree that it is challenging in Reverse.  Based on your feedback, I have just now changed Test 1 so that "T" and "e" and "s" are all very close to top left, and "t" is close to the bottom right corner, so hopefully that will help.  Test 6 (with just one letter) should also help in Reverse.

What do you think?

Thanks Lisa-Has-Ideas for your response and considering to update test 1 for an easier show of its derivation in reverse mode. 
Continuing there on, I would additionally suggest to keep its row 1 vacant (without those 'C' and 'O' in row 1, or shift 'T' from row 2 to row 1 if you wouldn't want to keep the first row blank) for more clear presence of the secretCode-indexed text characters there, similarly having the last row with just 't' present in entire row, that should improve it further for reverse mode.

It's mostly ready, and every improvement counts here. Good to see that test 1 updated for reverse mode ðŸ˜ƒ

Thanks.  Good suggestions... Done.
(How is it now?)

Seems better, feeling more confident with it now.

One more suggestion here (maybe good to have): How about including half the length of secretCode before providing secret code string (say 4 for 8 character secretCode for your current Test 1)? This would be useful for facilitating inputs and may further help in hinting on the use of the string in continuation. What do you think about it?

Oh, and I just noted while trying the problem before approving it, isn't row and column direction inobvious without mentioning about in the explanation? Your row seems to increment horizontally (unlike a matrix or Excel table where row changes vertically and column changes horizontally), should it be stated about in the problem statement or somehow just hinted at least?

(side comment: output of Validator 5 makes me ðŸ¤£, I always get delighted by your ideas and never feel as that)

Thanks!

re:
One more suggestion here (maybe good to have): How about including half the length of secretCode before providing secret code string (say 4 for 8 character secretCode for your current Test 1)? This would be useful for facilitating inputs and may further help in hinting on the use of the string in continuation. What do you think about it?

I don't think I understand.  Can you say it a different way please?

re:
Oh, and I just noted while trying the problem before approving it, isn't row and column direction inobvious without mentioning about in the explanation? Your row seems to increment horizontally (unlike a matrix or Excel table where row changes vertically and column changes horizontally), should it be stated about in the problem statement or somehow just hinted at least?

I think I have this right....  Double-check please.
And explain more what you mean by "Your row seems to increment horizontally".
How?  Where?

re:
(side comment: output of Validator 5 makes me ðŸ¤£, I always get delighted by your ideas and never feel as that)

Ahh, thanks.  It's a curse and a blessing.  :)

replying for:
>re: One more suggestion ... I don't think I understand.  Can you say it a different way please?

Sure. I should have left an example.
I meant to say to provide 2 lines of input for secretCode after 26X26 grid, one indicating half of its length (that is, length of its output) and keeping the current last line having secretCode after it

Example:
For your Test 1, rather than having just "AaCcFbYz", have it as 
"4 AaCcFbYz" (in _separate_ lines, half its length for indicating the count of coordinate pairs and expected length of output)

--- x ---

Replying for:
> I think I have this right....  Double-check please. And explain more what you mean by "Your row seems to increment horizontally". How?  Where?

My bad, I missed on that line stating that the first one is column and second one is row before the para having your example showing "AaCdZy" translating to (0,0), (2,3), (25,24). By the way, if you know that the first character is column and second one is row, shouldn't the convention be (0,0), (3,2) and (24,25) instead for this example (for (row, column) convention)?

Double-checking made me realize it is correct as it is not row which is incrementing horizontally, except the order of coordinate decoding example of a secretCode in the goal statement.
